problem:
\begin{problem*}{}{}
  Find all real polynomials $P(x)$ with $P(0)=0$ such that
  there exists a function $F(x)$ satisfying $F(x)> x$
  for all $x\ge 0$ and
  \[
  F(P(x))=P(F(x))\quad\forall x\in\mathbb R.
  \]
\end{problem*}
solution:
\begin{soln}
  Plugging $x=0$ gives
  \[
    P(F(0))=F(0).
  \]
  Composing $F$ on both sides, we get
  \[
    P(F^2(0))=F(P(F(0)))=F^2(0)
  .\]

  Similarly,
  \[
  P(F^n(0))= F^n(0)
  \implies P(F^{n+1}(0))=F(P(F^n(0)))= F^{n+1}(0)
  .\]

  Therefore,
  \[
    P(F^n(0))= F^n(0)\quad\forall\, n\in\NN.
  \]

  Let $Q(x)=P(x)-x$. Clearly $Q(x)$ is a real polynomial.

  As $F(0)>0$ and $F(x)> x$, we get
  \[
    F(0)>0 \implies F^2(0)>F(0)\implies
    \dotsb \implies F^n(0)>F^{n-1}(0).
  \]

  Hence, $\{F^n(0)\}_{n\ge 1}$ is a
  strictly increasing sequence.
  Therefore,
  \[
    Q(F^n(0))=0 \quad\forall\, n\in \NN,
  \]
  and since there are infinitely many zeroes of $Q$,
  this forces $Q \equiv 0$ which implies $P\equiv x$.
  For $P(x)= x$, we can pick $F(x)= x+1$,
  which clearly satisfies both conditions.
\end{soln}
